column5: Trigger Entity Configuration response
column6: Compliant if the authorization_endpoint claim contains "private", not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the AA metadata contain correct type authorization_endpoint claim
column11: In this test the AA metadata in the AA Entity Configuration are taken and the value of the authorization_endpoint claim in the 'federation_entity' entity type is "private"
column14: Entity Configuration response | body | [^\n\r]* | payload | .metadata.federation_entity | {"type": "object","properties": {"authorization_endpoint": {"type": "string","const": "private"}},"required": ["authorization_endpoint"]}
column15: The AA Metadata of type 'federation_entity' MUST contain authorization_endpoint

column5: Trigger Entity Configuration response
column6: Compliant if the logo_uri claim is an URL, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the AA metadata contain correct type logo_uri claim
column11: In this test the SA metadata in the TA Entity Configuration are taken and the value of the logo_uri claim in the 'federation_entity' entity type is an URL with an .svg file
column14: Entity Configuration response | body | [^\n\r]* | payload | .metadata.federation_entity | {"type":"object", "properties":{"logo_uri":{"type":"string", "format":"uri", "pattern":"^https://.*\\.svg$"}},"required":["logo_uri"]}
column15: The AA Metadata of type 'federation_entity' MUST contain logo_uri

column5: Trigger Entity Configuration response
column6: Compliant if the op_policy_uri claim is in the AA metadata, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the AA metadata contain op_policy_uri claim
column11: In this test the AA metadata in the AA Entity Configuration are taken and the presence of the op_policy_uri claim in the 'openid_provider' entity type is checked
column14: Entity Configuration response | body | [^\n\r]* | payload | .metadata.openid_provider.op_policy_uri
column15: The AA Metadata of type 'openid_provider' MUST contain op_policy_uri

column5: Trigger Entity Configuration response

column11: In this test the AA metadata in the AA Entity Configuration are taken and the value of the op_policy_uri claim in the 'openid_provider' entity type is "private"
column14: Entity Configuration response | body | [^\n\r]* | payload | .metadata.openid_provider | {"type": "object","properties": {"op_policy_uri": {"type": "string","format": "uri"}},"required": ["op_policy_uri"]}
column15: The AA Metadata of type 'openid_provider' MUST contain op_policy_uri as URL

column5: Trigger Entity Configuration response
column6: Compliant if the resource claim contains one or more https URL, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the AA metadata contain correct type resource claim
column11: In this test the AA metadata in the AA Entity Configuration are taken and the value of the resource claim in the 'federation_entity' entity type is an HTTPS URL
column14: Entity Configuration response | body | [^\n\r]* | payload | .metadata.federation_entity | {"type": "object","properties": {"resource": {"oneOf": [{"type": "string", "format": "uri", "pattern": "^https://"},{"type": "array","items": {"type": "string", "format": "uri", "pattern": "^https://"},"minItems": 1}]}},"required": ["resource"]}
column15: The AA Metadata of type 'federation_entity' MUST contain resource

column27: external tests from spid-oidc-check-op have an implementation issue: in those tests the presence of the claims is directly in the "Metadata" parameter of the document. In CIE federation instead, in the metadata paramter there are two subclaims ( "federation_entity" and "openid_relying_party") and the claims that the tests checks are in the "federation_entity" subclaim. (For details see coverage.md)

column5: Trigger Entity Configuration response
column6: Compliant if each key in metadata is a value between 'openid_relying_party', 'openid_provider', 'federation_entity', 'oauth_authorization_server', 'oauth_resource', not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the metadata parameter contain only allowed types
column11: To accomplish this test, the Entity configuration of the interested entity is taken, the payload is decoded (Base64 encoding) and the metadata parameter is analyzed. This must be a JSON object with each key representing a type of metadata. These types must be a value among the following: 'openid_relying_party', 'openid_provider', 'federation_entity', 'oauth_authorization_server', 'oauth_resource'
column14: Entity Configuration response | body | [^\n\r]* | payload | .metadata | {"type": "object","anyOf": [{"required": ["openid_relying_party"]},{"required": ["openid_provider"]},{"required": ["federation_entity"]},{"required": ["oauth_authorization_server"]},{"required": ["oauth_resource"]}],"properties": {"openid_relying_party":{"type":"object"},"openid_provider":{"type":"object"},"federation_entity":{"type":"object"},"oauth_authorization_server":{"type":"object"},"oauth_resource":{"type":"object"}}, "additionalProperties": false}
column15: Allowed metadata types are: 'openid_relying_party', 'openid_provider', 'federation_entity', 'oauth_authorization_server', 'oauth_resource'

column5: Trigger Entity Configuration response

column5: Entity Configuration request
column6: Compliant if the Content-Type of the response is application/entity-statement+jwt, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the entity return a correct Content-Type in the EC response
column11: In this test a correct request to the entity's /.well-known/openid-federation endpoint is made and the response is analyzed. It must have a Content-Type parameter set to application/entity-statement+jwt
column14: Entity Configuration response | head | Content-Type | application/entity-statement+jwt

column5: Entity Configuration request

column5: Trigger Entity Configuration response
column6: Compliant if the response is the Entity Configuration of the entity, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the entity configuration of a considered entity return a Federation Metadata in JOSE format when an HTTP GET request is made to its .well-known/openid-federation endpoint
column11: The considered entity must have published its entity configuration in the .well-known/openid-federation endpoint. So in this test, an HTTP GET request is made to the entity's .well-known/openid-federation endpoint (appended to the URL which identifies the entity) and the response is analyzed. This response has to be the entity configuration of the entity and therefore a Federation Metadata in JOSE format (Content-Type: application/entity-statement+jwt)
column14: Entity Configuration response | body | ([\w=]+)\.([\w=]+)\.([\w\-\+\/=]*)
column15: An Entity Configuration (EC) is a Federation Metadata in Jose format, signed by its issuing subject and regarding itself, published at the web endpoint .well-known/openid-federation.

column15: If the prompt parameter is set to consent login, the OP forces an authentication request to the user. Then it asks permission to transfer the claims. If the prompt parameter is set to consent, if a Single Sign On session is not yet active, the OP makes an Authentication Request to the user. Then it asks permission to transfer the claims.

column3: Authentication Response to a request with a request parameter signed with a symmetric algorithm
column4: Authentication Response to a request with a request parameter signed with a symmetric algorithm

column6: Compliant if the Authentication response is an HTTP 302 because of unauthorized_client, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the OP refuse Authentication Requests signed with a non-asymmetric method
column11: This test aims to check if the OP correctly handles the signature of the Authentication request: If the OP is not able to decrypt the signature, than the public key of the RP is wrong or, otherwise, the algorithm used is not known. If, instead, the OP is able to decrypt the signature, it can mean that the public key is correct and the algorithm known, or that the RP used a symmetric algorithm and the RP's key is the same key used to sign the JWT. In the latter case the confidentiality and integrity of the message cannot be trusted. In this case, the OP must check the 'alg' parameter in the JWT Header and, if it corresponds to a symmetric algorithm or to 'none', it must refuse the authentication request. In order to accomplish this test, a crafted RP could set in its metadata a symmetric key, use it to sign the JWT and send an Authentication Request. Another way to accomplish the test is by intercepting the request, changing the parameter and the signature.

In order to verify if the OP validates this trust chain, the authority_hints in the Entity Configuration of the RP could contain wrong values. If the OP validates the request anyway, it is not compliant with the specification

The OP should check the parameter and, seen that it is an invalid one, refuse the authentication request.

column10: Does the OP refuse Authentication Requests with a wrong iss parameter
column11: The 'iss' parameter in the JWT of an authentication request says who sent the request. If one request has a wrong iss, than it could be forwarded by a malicious user, so the iss must be checked. In order to test this behavior in the OP, an Authenticaton request is sent with a wrong iss (not the RP's client id) and the answer is analyzed

column5: Authentication Request with the request parameter with a wrong signature in the URL
column6: Compliant if the Authentication response is an HTTP 302 because of unauthorized_client, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the OP refuse wrongly signed Authentication Requests
column11: This test aims to check if the OP correctly handles the signature of the Authentication request: once received the request, the JWT token must be split in its 3 parts (header, payload, signature), base64url decoded and the signature must be verified. In order to test if the OP really checks the signature, the Authentication request is intercepted before arriving to the OP and the signature is changed. If the OP grants the tokens anyway, than it did not check the signature.
column13: Authentication request | url | request | X_wrong_key
column14: Authentication error response | head | 302 | head | unauthorized_client
column15: The Authorization request is initiated by the user that selects the OP for the authentication. The RP redirects the user to the Authorization Endpoint of the selected OP, including in the request the parameter request that is a signed JWT containing the Authorization Request.
column20: An inaccurate signature poses challenges in maintaining confidentiality and integrity.
column21: Is the JWT signature checked (IsSignatureChecked)

column5: Trigger Entity Configuration response
column6: Compliant if the signature is correct, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the entity correctly sign the Entity Configuration
column11: To accomplish this test, the Entity configuration of the interested entity is taken and the three parts of the JWT (header, payload and signature) are base64url decoded. Finally, the signature is validated passing the public key (n, e of jwks parameter that must be taken from the Entity Statement of a superior), the JWS Signature (received signature base64url decoded) and the JWS signing input (header and payload base64url encoded and concatenated with a dot dividing them) to a signature verifier configured for the algorithm described in the Entity Configuration Header
column14: Entity Configuration response | body | [^\r\n]* | X_key_ALL
column15: Entity Configurations must be signed

column6: Compliant if the signature of the Access Token is correctly verified using the OP's public key, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the OP correctly sign the Access Token
column11: Tokens issued by an OP must have the structure of JWT Tokens. In particular, this structure is composed by three base64url encoded strings separated by dots, namely the header, payload and signature. The signature is made using the OP's private key, in such a way to be decrypted using its public key. In this test a normal flow is performed and the obtained Access Token is analyzed. In order to test if the OP correctly signed the signature part of the JWT, the access token is passed to a signature verifier correctly configured

column5: Trigger Token response
column6: Compliant if the signature part of the ID Token is correctly verified using the OP's public key, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the OP correctly sign the ID Token
column11: Tokens issued by an OP must have the structure of JWT Tokens. In particular, this structure is composed by three base64url encoded strings separated by dots, namely the header, payload and signature. The signature is made using the OP's private key, in such a way to be decrypted using its public key. In this test a normal flow is performed and the obtained ID Token is analyzed. In order to test if the OP correctly signed the signature part of the JWT, the third part of the string is taken and passed to a signature verifier correctly configured

The signature is made using the OP's private key, in such a way to be decrypted using its public key. In this test an offline_access flow is performed and the obtained Refresh token is analyzed. In order to test if the OP correctly signed the signature part of the JWT, the Refresh token is passed to a signature verifier correctly configured

column10: Does the OP release only previously accepted information when presenting a refresh token
column11: In this test the offline_access flow is accomplished, obtaining a refresh token and an access token. After this, a UserInfo request is sent with the access token and the released information saved. Once obtained the information, a new token request is done with 'grant_type=refresh_token' and the refresh token inserted in the 'refresh_token' parameter. The access token included in the latter response is then taken, a UserInfo Request is made with it and the results compared. The last UserInfo Response must contain exactly the claims issued with the previous one
column15: The Refresh Token MAY be used as a mechanism to obtain from the UserInfo endpoint only the same set of user attributes requested at the initial authentication phase and for which the user has given explicit consent

column15: The JWT Header of the request parameter in the Authentication Request must contain the 'alg' parameter, it must be set to one of the supported values for the OP metadata and must not be 'none' or a symmetric algorithm (MAC).
column27:
If it is not an alg supported by the OP, than it cannot verify the signature and there are 3 cases: 1. It is a algorithm not supported and the OP even trying to use the correct RP's public key cannot decrypt it, or
2. It is a symmetric algorithm and the public key of the RP won't decrypt the signature
3. It is a symmetric algorithm and the public key of the RP is the correct key used to encrypt it
In the first 2 cases the parameter is meaningless because the OP won't be able to decrypt the signature, in the latter we cannot rely on the secrecy of the process. The only interesting case is the third one

column3: OP's Entity Configuration and TA's Entity Statement for the OP with a public key that differs from the one in the EC of the OP
column5: Entity Statement response regarding the OP and with a wrong jwks parameter and Authentication request
column6: Compliant if the authentication response does not contain the code parameter, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the RP request the OP's Entity Statement to validate the OP's Entity Configuration
column11: In order to check if the RP verifies the OP's Entity Configuration with the keys sent in the ES, once the RP asks for the Entity Statement, the TA's Entity Statement in response could have a (wrong) public key that is different from the one that can be found in the OP's EC (ES keys should be wrong). After this, an authentication request with that OP is made and, if the response contains the code parameter, the RP is either using the public keys present in the Entity Configuration (not reliable) or not checking the signature at all.
column15: For each EC of the OPs, the RP validates the signature by using the public key obtained in the Entity Statement released by the Trust Anchor.
column20: An inaccurate signature poses challenges in maintaining confidentiality and integrity.
column27: The test fails if a correct flow is accomplished by the RP. It is similar to JWT response (correct check-no) but since we are checking the RP's flow, we do not except an HTTP Error code

column5: Entity Configuration response containing a wrongly-signed Entity Configuration
column6: Compliant if the Authentication response does not contain the code parameter, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the RP check the signature in the OP Entity Configuration
column11: In order to check if the RP correctly verifies the signature of an OP's Entity Configuration and does not trust arbitrary OP, the latter sends as the Entity Configuration response a wrongly signed Entity Configuration and waits for the RP. After this an authentication request is sent and, if the response contains the code, the RP is not checking the authenticity of the EC
column15: For each EC of the OPs, the RP validates the signature by using the public key obtained in the Entity Statement released by the Trust Anchor.
column20: An inaccurate signature poses challenges in maintaining confidentiality and integrity.

column27: external tests from spid-oidc-check-op have an implementation issue: in those tests the presence of the claims is directly in the "Metadata" parameter of the document. In CIE federation instead, in the metadata paramter there are two subclaims ( "federation_entity" and "openid_relying_party") and the claims that the tests checks are in the "federation_entity" subclaim. (For details see coverage.md)

column27: external tests from spid-oidc-check-op have an implementation issue: in those tests the presence of the claims is directly in the "Metadata" parameter of the document. In CIE federation instead, in the metadata paramter there are two subclaims ( "federation_entity" and "openid_relying_party") and the claims that the tests checks are in the "federation_entity" subclaim. (For details see coverage.md)

column3: SA's fetch Entity Statement Endpoint response regarding the Entity we are considering
column5: Trigger Entity Statement response SA OP
column6: Compliant if the SA's return the Entity Statement regarding the Entity we are considering, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the SA correctly release the Entity statements
column11: After a correct onboarding with the SA, it must publish the entity statement for the subordinate entity in its fetch endpoint. So, in this test, once correctly registered an Entity, an HTTP GET request is made to the SA's fetch endpoint, with the request containing the Entity identifier. The response is then checked and it must contain the subordinate entity's Entity Statement.
column14: Entity Statement response SA OP | body | [^\r\n]*.^([\w=]+)\.([\w=]+)\.([\w\-\+\/=]*)
column15: The Federation Authority or an Intermediary MUST publish the Leaf Entity Statement containing the Federation public keys of the onboarded Entity and the TMs released for it. An Entity publishes an ES related to a subordinate, at its Fetch Endpoint.

column3: Entity statement issued by the SA
column5: Trigger Entity Statement response SA OP
column6: Compliant if the signature is verified, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the SA correctly signs the Entity Statement
column11: In order to validate the signature of an Entity statement issued by an SA, the statement is taken and the three parts of the JWT (header, payload and signature) are base64url decoded. Finally, the signature is validated passing the public key (n, e of jwks parameter of the Entity Statement of the SA issued from the TA), the JWS Signature (received signature base64url decoded) and the JWS signing input (header and payload base64url encoded and concatenated with a dot dividing them) to a signature verifier configured for the algorithm described in the Entity Statement Header
column14: Entity Statement response SA OP | body | [^\r\n]* | X_key_SA
column15: Entity Statements must be signed
column20: An inaccurate signature poses challenges in maintaining confidentiality and integrity.

column3: Trust Mark generated by TA or SA
column5: Trigger Entity Statement response SA OP
column6: Compliant if the signature of the trust marks in the entity statement is valid, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the SA correctly sign the Trust marks
column11: To accomplish this test, an entity statement issued by the SA is taken, and the trust marks in it are taken. The three parts of the JWT (header, payload and signature) composing the trust marks are base64url decoded. Finally, the signature is validated passing the public key (n, e of jwks parameter), the JWS Signature (received signature base64url decoded) and the JWS signing input (header and payload base64url encoded and concatenated with a dot dividing them) to a signature verifier.
column14: Entity Statement response SA OP | body | [^\r\n]* | payload | trust_marks | trust_mark | X_key_SA
column15: The Trust Marks (TM) are signed JWT
column20: An inaccurate signature poses challenges in maintaining confidentiality and integrity.

Therefore, the Entity Statement Payload contained in the response are base64url decoded, once obtained the decrypted Payload, the presence if the trust_marks parameter is checked

column15: The trust_marks parameter is required in the Entity Statement released by the SA

column15: The metadata_policy parameter is required in the Entity Statement released by the SA

column3: Metadata policy in an Entity Statement issued by the SA
column5: Trigger Entity Statement response SA RP
column6: Compliant if the jwks parameter is present in the openid_relying_party type and it contains the RP's JWKS (type json), not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the SA's metadata policy for an RP contain the jwks parameter
column11: In order to check the compliance of a metadata policy issued by the SA, an entity statement for an RP must be fetched in the SA's fetch endpoint. Once obtained the entity statement, the metadata_policy parameter is taken and the presence of the jwks parameter inside the openid_relying_party type is checked. It must contain the RP JWKS related to the OIDC Core operations
column14: Entity Statement response SA RP | body | [^\n\r]* | payload | .metadata_policy.openid_relying_party.jwks | {"type":"object", "properties": {"value" :{}}, "required": ["value"]}
column15: The jwks claim MUST be considered in the metadata parameter of type 'openid_relying_party' within the policy that an SA establishes for an RP that is its direct descendant

column3: SA's fetch Entity Statement Endpoint response regarding the Entity we are considering
column5: Trigger Entity Statement response SA RP
column6: Compliant if the SA's return the Entity Statement regarding the Entity we are considering, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the SA correctly release the Entity statements
column11: After a correct onboarding with the SA, it must publish the entity statement for the subordinate entity in its fetch endpoint. So, in this test, once correctly registered an Entity, an HTTP GET request is made to the SA's fetch endpoint, with the request containing the Entity identifier. The response is then checked and it must contain the subordinate entity's Entity Statement.
column14: Entity Statement response SA RP | body | [^\r\n]*.^([\w=]+)\.([\w=]+)\.([\w\-\+\/=]*)
column15: The Federation Authority or an Intermediary MUST publish the Leaf Entity Statement containing the Federation public keys of the onboarded Entity and the TMs released for it. An Entity publishes an ES related to a subordinate, at its Fetch Endpoint.

column3: Entity statement issued by the SA
column5: Trigger Entity Statement response SA RP
column6: Compliant if the signature is verified, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the SA correctly signs the Entity Statement
column11: In order to validate the signature of an Entity statement issued by an SA, the statement is taken and the three parts of the JWT (header, payload and signature) are base64url decoded. Finally, the signature is validated passing the public key (n, e of jwks parameter of the Entity Statement of the SA issued from the TA), the JWS Signature (received signature base64url decoded) and the JWS signing input (header and payload base64url encoded and concatenated with a dot dividing them) to a signature verifier configured for the algorithm described in the Entity Statement Header
column14: Entity Statement response SA RP | body | [^\r\n]* | X_key_SA
column15: Entity Statements must be signed
column20: An inaccurate signature poses challenges in maintaining confidentiality and integrity.

Therefore, the Entity Statement Payload contained in the response are base64url decoded, once obtained the decrypted Payload, the presence if the sub parameter is checked
column14: Entity Statement response SA RP | body | [^\r\n]* | payload | sub
column15: The sub parameter is required in the Entity Statement released by the SA

column11: The id of the trust mark must have the structure <SA domain>/<entity_type>/<trustmark_profile>/. So in this test, an issued Trust Mark must be taken, decrypted and the presence of the id claim in it is checked. If it is present, than the structure of the id must be as described above. column3: Trust Mark generated by TA or SA
column5: Trigger Entity Statement response SA RP
column6: Compliant if the signature of the trust marks in the entity statement is valid, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the SA correctly sign the Trust marks
column11: To accomplish this test, an entity statement issued by the SA is taken, and the trust marks in it are taken. The three parts of the JWT (header, payload and signature) composing the trust marks are base64url decoded. Finally, the signature is validated passing the public key (n, e of jwks parameter), the JWS Signature (received signature base64url decoded) and the JWS signing input (header and payload base64url encoded and concatenated with a dot dividing them) to a signature verifier.
column14: Entity Statement response SA RP | body | [^\r\n]* | payload | trust_marks | trust_mark | X_key_SA
column15: The Trust Marks (TM) are signed JWT
column20: An inaccurate signature poses challenges in maintaining confidentiality and integrity.

Therefore, the Entity Statement Payload contained in the response are base64url decoded, once obtained the decrypted Payload, the presence if the trust_marks parameter is checked

column11: In order to check the presence and correctness of the fetch entity statement endpoint, an HTTP GET request containing the parameters 'iss' and 'sub' is made to the entity's endpoint and a response containing the resolved metadata for the entity in the request's sub claim is expected.
column14: Fetch Entity Statement response SA RP | body | [^\r\n]*.^([\w=]+)\.([\w=]+)\.([\w\-\+\/=]*)

column11: To check if the trust mark status endpoint accurately verifies valid trust marks, valid trust marks obtained directly from the OP Entity Configuration response can be sent to the endpoint dynamically according to the 'iss' of the trust mark, and the response can be analyzed.
column15: In addition to the Federation endpoints reported before, the Entities of type TA or SA MUST provide the trust mark status endpoint. It allows an Entity to test if a TM is still active or not.
column20: The severity is based on whether the TM is still active or not

column5: Trust Mark status endpoint request with invalidated Trust Mark
column6: Compliant if the response contains an active claim set to false, not compliant otherwise

column11: In order to check if a SA correctly invalidate a Trust Mark, a Trust Mark revocation request on a Trust Mark has to be made and then the trust mark status endpoint must be fetched. If the response says that the trust mark is invalid, than it is correctly invalidated, otherwise the SA is not compliant with the specification

column27: external tests from spid-oidc-check-op have an implementation issue: in those tests the presence of the claims is directly in the "Metadata" parameter of the document. In CIE federation instead, in the metadata paramter there are two subclaims ( "federation_entity" and "openid_relying_party") and the claims that the tests checks are in the "federation_entity" subclaim. (For details see coverage.md)

column3: HTTP response from the authorization endpoint
column6: Compliant if the server returns an HTTP error, not compliant otherwise
column10: OP authentication requests use HTTPS
column11: This test is performed trying to make a request to the Authorization endpoint with http and not with https. If the endpoint refuses the connection, then the use of HTTPS is required and thus, the server respects the specification. If otherwise the request is accepted, it means that the server automatically upgrades to HTTPS and then it is not compliant with the specifications.
column21: Is HTTPS required at the authorization endpoint (IsHttpsRequired)
column27: It is trivial but in the specification is not specified for the authorization endpoint to have an HTTPS URL

column3: HTTP response from the revocation endpoint
column6: Compliant if the server returns an HTTP error, not compliant otherwise
column10: OP revocation requests use HTTPS
column11: This test is performed trying to make a request to the Revocation endpoint with http and not https. If the endpoint refuses the connection, then the use of HTTPS is required and thus, the server respects the specification. If otherwise the request is accepted, it means that the server automatically upgrades to HTTPS and then it is not compliant with the specifications.
column21: Is the revocation endpoint secure (IsRevocationEndpointSecure)
column22: Uses https for all endpoints unless only using code flow
column27: It is trivial but in the specification is not specified for the revocation endpoint to have an HTTPS URL

column3: Revocation response to revocation request without any authentication
column6: Compliant if the server rejects the request, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does revocation require client authentication (IsClientAuthRequired)
column11: This test checks if the revocation endpoint requires client authentication.

column27: Cannot understand what they mean for authentication method

column6: Compliant if newer TLS protocols are supported, not compliant otherwise

column27: Not required in the specification. Did not understand how the test works

column3: Userinfo response to a POST request with the token in the body
column6: Compliant if the response is an HTTP 200 OK and thus the server accepts the token in the body, not compliant otherwise
column10: Userinfo Endpoint access with form-encoded body method
column11: This tests makes an authenticated POST request to the UserInfo endpoint with the access token in the body and validates the response. Support for passing an access token in the request body is not required by the standards - if is acceptable for servers not to implement this form, and the test will complete with a 'warning' if the server returns a http error response.
column16: External: OpenID Connect Conformance Profiles v3.0
column22: Userinfo Endpoint access with form-encoded body method
column27: Nothing about this in the specification

column6: None

column3: TA's fetch Entity Statement Endpoint response regarding the Entity we are considering
column5: Trigger Entity Statement response TA OP
column6: Compliant if the TA's return the Entity Statement regarding the Entity we are considering, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the TA correctly release the Entity statements
column11: After a correct onboarding with the TA, it must publish the entity statement for the subordinate entity in its fetch endpoint. So, in this test, once correctly registered an Entity, an HTTP GET request is made to the TA's fetch endpoint, with the request containing the Entity identifier. The response is then checked and it must contain the subordinate entity's Entity Statement.
column14: Entity Statement response TA OP | body | ([\w=]+)\.([\w=]+)\.([\w\-\+\/=]*)
column15: The Federation Authority or an Intermediary MUST publish the Leaf Entity Statement containing the Federation public keys of the onboarded Entity and the TMs released for it.

column3: Entity Statement issued by the TA
column5: Trigger Entity Statement response TA OP
column6: Compliant if the signature is verified, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the TA correctly sign the Entity statements
column11: In order to validate the signature of an Entity statement issued by the TA, the statement is taken and the three parts of the JWT (header, payload and signature) are base64url decoded. Finally, the signature is validated passing the public key (n, e of jwks parameter of the entity configuration), the JWS Signature (received signature base64url decoded) and the JWS signing input (header and payload base64url encoded and concatenated with a dot dividing them) to a signature verifier configured for the algorithm described in the Entity Statement Header
column14: Entity Statement response TA OP | body | [^\r\n]* | X_key_TA
column15: Entity Statements must be signed
column20: An inaccurate signature poses challenges in maintaining confidentiality and integrity.

column3: Entity Statement issued by the TA
column5: Trigger Entity Statement response TA OP
column6: Compliant if the sub parameter is present, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does Entity Statements issued by the TA contain the sub parameter
column11: In order to check if the TA issues correct Entity statements, a request for an entity statement is made (HTTP GET request in the TA's fetch endpoint) and the response is analyzed. Therefore, the Entity Statement Payload contained in the response are base64url decoded, once obtained the decrypted Payload, the presence if the sub parameter is checked
column14: Entity Statement response TA OP | body | [^\r\n]* | payload | sub
column15: The sub parameter is required in the Entity Statement released by the TA

column3: Trust Mark generated for an AA
column5: Trigger Entity Statement response TA OP
column6: Compliant if the claims claim is present in the trust mark payload, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the issued oauth_resource Trust Mark contain the claims claim
column11: In this test, a Trust Mark issued for an TA must be taken, decrypted and the presence of the claims claim in it is checked.
column14: Entity Statement response TA OP | body | [^\r\n]* | payload | trust_marks[0].trust_mark | payload | claims
column15: In addition to the claims of the public and private profiles, the profile oauth_resource identifies the AA and adds the claims claim:

column3: Trust Mark generated for an AA
column5: Trigger Entity Statement response TA OP
column6: Compliant if the claims claim is a list of JSON Objects, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the issued oauth_resource Trust Mark contain a correct claims claim
column11: In this test, a Trust Mark issued for an AA (oauth_resource profile) must be taken, decrypted and the value of the claims claim has to be a list of JSON Objects
column14: Entity Statement response TA OP | body | [^\r\n]* | payload | trust_marks[0].trust_mark | payload |  | {"type": "object", "properties": {"claims": {"type": "object", "additionalProperties": {"type": "object"}}},"required": ["claims"]}
column15: In addition to the claims of the public and private profiles, the profile oauth_resource identifies the AA and adds the claims claim:

column15: The issued Trust Marks must have the email claim

column15: The vat_number claim is required in the id_code claim of Trust Marks issued for private Organizations if there is not the fiscal_number claim. The fiscal_number claim is required in the id_code claim of Trust Marks issued for private Organizations if there is not the vat_number claim

column3: Trust Mark generated by TA or SA

column11: The id of the trust mark must be present. So in this test, an issued Trust Mark must be taken, decrypted and the presence of the id claim in it is checked.

column3: Entity statement issued by the TA
column5: Trigger Entity Statement response TA OP
column6: Compliant if the signature is valid, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the TA correctly sign the issued Trust Mark
column11: To accomplish this test, a Trust Mark issued by the TA is taken and the three parts of the JWT (header, payload and signature) are base64url decoded. Finally, the signature is validated passing the public key (n, e of jwks parameter), the JWS Signature (received signature base64url decoded) and the JWS signing input (header and payload base64url encoded and concatenated with a dot dividing them) to a signature verifier.
column14: Entity Statement response TA OP | body | [^\r\n]* | payload | trust_marks | trust_mark | X_key_TA
column15: The Trust Marks (TM) are signed JWT
column20: An inaccurate signature poses challenges in maintaining confidentiality and integrity.

column3: TA's fetch Entity Statement Endpoint response regarding the Entity we are considering
column5: Trigger Entity Statement response TA RP
column6: Compliant if the TA's return the Entity Statement regarding the Entity we are considering, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the TA correctly release the Entity statements
column11: After a correct onboarding with the TA, it must publish the entity statement for the subordinate entity in its fetch endpoint. So, in this test, once correctly registered an Entity, an HTTP GET request is made to the TA's fetch endpoint, with the request containing the Entity identifier. The response is then checked and it must contain the subordinate entity's Entity Statement.
column14: Entity Statement response TA RP | body | ([\w=]+)\.([\w=]+)\.([\w\-\+\/=]*)
column15: The Federation Authority or an Intermediary MUST publish the Leaf Entity Statement containing the Federation public keys of the onboarded Entity and the TMs released for it.

column3: Entity Statement issued by the TA
column5: Trigger Entity Statement response TA RP
column6: Compliant if the signature is verified, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the TA correctly sign the Entity statements
column11: In order to validate the signature of an Entity statement issued by the TA, the statement is taken and the three parts of the JWT (header, payload and signature) are base64url decoded. Finally, the signature is validated passing the public key (n, e of jwks parameter of the entity configuration), the JWS Signature (received signature base64url decoded) and the JWS signing input (header and payload base64url encoded and concatenated with a dot dividing them) to a signature verifier configured for the algorithm described in the Entity Statement Header
column14: Entity Statement response TA RP | body | [^\r\n]* | X_key_TA
column15: Entity Statements must be signed
column20: An inaccurate signature poses challenges in maintaining confidentiality and integrity.

column3: Entity Statement issued by the TA
column5: Trigger Entity Statement response TA RP
column6: Compliant if the sub parameter is present, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does Entity Statements issued by the TA contain the sub parameter
column11: In order to check if the TA issues correct Entity statements, a request for an entity statement is made (HTTP GET request in the TA's fetch endpoint) and the response is analyzed. Therefore, the Entity Statement Payload contained in the response are base64url decoded, once obtained the decrypted Payload, the presence if the sub parameter is checked
column14: Entity Statement response TA RP | body | [^\r\n]* | payload | sub
column15: The sub parameter is required in the Entity Statement released by the TA

column3: Trust Mark generated for an AA
column5: Trigger Entity Statement response TA RP
column6: Compliant if the claims claim is present in the trust mark payload, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the issued oauth_resource Trust Mark contain the claims claim
column11: In this test, a Trust Mark issued for an AA (oauth_resource profile) must be taken, decrypted and the presence of the claims claim in it is checked.
column14: Entity Statement response TA RP | body | [^\r\n]* | payload | trust_marks[0].trust_mark | payload | claims
column15: In addition to the claims of the public and private profiles, the profile oauth_resource identifies the AA and adds the claims claim:

column3: Trust Mark generated for an AA
column5: Trigger Entity Statement response TA RP
column6: Compliant if the claims claim is a list of JSON Objects, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the issued oauth_resource Trust Mark contain a correct claims claim
column11: In this test, a Trust Mark issued for an AA (oauth_resource profile) must be taken, decrypted and the value of the claims claim has to be a list of JSON Objects
column14: Entity Statement response TA RP | body | [^\r\n]* | payload | trust_marks[0].trust_mark | payload |  | {"type": "object", "properties": {"claims": {"type": "object", "additionalProperties": {"type": "object"}}},"required": ["claims"]}
column15: In addition to the claims of the public and private profiles, the profile oauth_resource identifies the AA and adds the claims claim:

column14: Entity Statement response TA RP | body | [^\r\n]* | payload | trust_marks[0].trust_mark | payload |  | {  "type ":  "object ",  "properties ": {  "email ": {  "type ":  "string ",  "format ":  "email " } },  "required ": [ "email "] }
column15: The issued Trust Marks must have the email claim as string

column14: Entity Statement response TA RP | body | [^\r\n]* | payload | trust_marks[0].trust_mark | payload |  | {"type": "object", "properties": {"id_code": {"type":"object", "properties": {"fiscal_number": {}, "vat_number":{}},"anyOf":[{"required":["fiscal_number"]},{"required":["vat_number"]}]}},"required":["id_code"]}
column15: The vat_number claim is required in the id_code claim of Trust Marks issued for private Organizations if there is not the fiscal_number claim. The fiscal_number claim is required in the id_code claim of Trust Marks issued for private Organizations if there is not the vat_number claim

column3: Trust Mark generated by TA or SA

column6: Compliant if the id claim is present in the trust mark, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the Trust Mark contain the id claim
column11: The id of the trust mark must be present. So in this test, an issued Trust Mark must be taken, decrypted and the presence of the id claim in it is checked.

column10: Does the Trust Mark contain a correct id claim
column11: The id of the trust mark must have the structure <TA domain>/<entity_type>/<trustmark_profile>/. So in this test, an issued Trust Mark must be taken, decrypted and the value of the id claim can be one among 'openid_relying_party', 'openid_provider', 'intermediary' 'oauth_resource', whereas the trustmark profile can be 'public' or 'private'
column14: Entity Statement response TA RP | body | [^\r\n]* | payload | trust_marks | trust_mark | payload | id | openid_relying_party | openid_provider | intermediate | oauth_resource
column15: The issued Trust Marks must have the id claim. The id in the trust mark is an URL with the following structure: <TA domain>/<entity_type>/<trustmark_profile>/

column15: The ipa_code claim is required in the id_code claim of Trust Marks issued for public Organizations

column3: Entity statement issued by the TA
column5: Trigger Entity Statement response TA RP
column6: Compliant if the signature is valid, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the TA correctly sign the issued Trust Mark
column11: To accomplish this test, a Trust Mark issued by the TA is taken and the three parts of the JWT (header, payload and signature) are base64url decoded. Finally, the signature is validated passing the public key (n, e of jwks parameter), the JWS Signature (received signature base64url decoded) and the JWS signing input (header and payload base64url encoded and concatenated with a dot dividing them) to a signature verifier.
column14: Entity Statement response TA RP | body | [^\r\n]* | payload | trust_marks | trust_mark | X_key_TA
column15: The Trust Marks (TM) are signed JWT
column20: An inaccurate signature poses challenges in maintaining confidentiality and integrity.

column6: Compliant if the trust_marks parameter is present, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does Entity Statements issued by the TA contain the trust_marks parameter
column11: In order to check if the TA issues correct Entity statements, a request for an entity statement is made (HTTP GET request in the TA's fetch endpoint) and the response is analyzed. Therefore, the Entity Statement Payload contained in the response are base64url decoded, once obtained the decrypted Payload, the presence if the trust_marks parameter is checked

column14: Entity Statement response TA SA | body | [^\r\n]* | payload | trust_marks[0].trust_mark | payload | sa_profile
column15: In addition to the claims of the public and private profiles, the profile intermediary identifies the SA and adds the extensions full and light in the sa_profile claim, according to the ways of operation towards the subordinate Entities.

column10: Does the Entity expose the fetch entity statement endpoint
column11: In order to check the presence and correctness of the fetch entity statement endpoint, an HTTP GET request containing the parameters 'iss' and 'sub' is made to the entity's endpoint and a response containing the resolved metadata for the entity in the request's sub claim is expected.
column14: Fetch Entity Statement response TA OP | body | ([\w=]+)\.([\w=]+)\.([\w\-\+\/=]*)
column15: In addition to the Federation endpoints reported before, the Entities of type TA or SA MUST provide the fetch entity statement endpoint. It returns the ESs regarding a direct subordinate subject. For obtaining the ES of an Entity, at least its Entity identifier is needed

column5: Trigger Public Keys History response
column6: Compliant if the response contains a JWT, not compliant otherwise
column10: Does the TA publish the federation public key history
column11: An HTTP Get request is made to the TA's /.well-known/openid-federation-jwks endpoint and the answer is analyzed
column14: Public Keys History response | body | \[\s*"[^"]*"(?:,\s*"[^"]*")*\s*\]$
column15: In order to enable the verification of messages exchanged by Entities participating in the federation and their Trust Chains, the TA MUST publish the federation public key history (JWKS) within a registry made available to all participants via the /.well-known/openid-federation-jwks endpoint.

column5: Trigger Trust Mark status response TA OP
column6: HTTP 200 OK response containing the claim 'active' set to true
column10: Does the TA Trust Mark Status endpoint effectively verify valid Trust Marks of OP
column11: To check if the trust mark status endpoint accurately verifies valid trust marks, valid trust marks obtained directly from the OP Entity Configuration response can be sent to the endpoint dynamically according to the 'iss' of the trust mark, and the response can be analyzed.
column15: In addition to the Federation endpoints reported before, the Entities of type TA or SA MUST provide the trust mark status endpoint. It allows an Entity to test if a TM is still active or not.

column5: Trust Mark status request with a non-valid Trust Mark

column10: Does the TA's trust mark status endpoint correctly refuses a not-valid id Trust Marks OP
column11: In order to check if the trust mark status endpoint of a TA correctly refuses invalid trust marks OP, a invalid trust mark can be sent to the endpoint and the response analyzed
column15: A Trust Mark can be revoked at any moment only and exclusively by the issuing subject. In case of TM revocation, the dynamic validation gives a negative result
column20: The severity is based on whether the TM is still active or not

column4: Trust Mark status response TA (endpoint response)

column10: Does the TA invalidate revocated trust marks
column11: In order to check if a TA correctly invalidate a Trust Mark, a Trust Mark revocation request on a Trust Mark has to be made and then the trust mark status endpoint must be fetched. If the response says that the trust mark is invalid, than it is correctly invalidated, otherwise the TA is not compliant with the specification
